title: Share with access to electricity vs. per capita energy consumption

title: Agricultural export subsidies
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agricultural-export-subsidies?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

subtitle: The annual monetary value of gross transfers to general services provided to agricultural producers collectively (such as research, development, training, inspection, marketing and promotion), arising from policy measures that support agriculture regardless of their nature, objectives and impacts on farm production, income, or consumption. This does not include any transfers to individual producers.

subtitle: Organic arable land area is the sum of the area certified as organic by official standards, and land area in the conversion process to organic (which is assumed by the UN FAO as a two-year period prior to certification). Arable land is that used for crops (which does not include grazing land).

title: Share of cereals allocated to animal feed
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-cereals-animal-feed?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of domestic cereal supply – after correcting for trade – which is allocated to animal feed, as opposed to being used for direct human consumption or industrial uses (such as biofuel production).

title: Share of cereals allocated to food, animal feed or fuel
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cereal-allocation-by-country?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Share of cereals allocated to human food
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-cereal-human-food?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of domestic cereal supply – after correcting for trade – which is allocated to direct human consumption, as opposed to being used for animal feed or industrial uses (such as biofuel production).

title: Share of cereals allocated to human food vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cereals-human-food-vs-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of domestic cereal supply allocated to direct human food, rather than animal feed or biofuels. GDP is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living across countries.

title: Share of cereals allocated to industrial uses
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-cereals-industrial-uses?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of domestic cereal supply – after correcting for trade – which is allocated to other uses (primarily industrial uses such as biofuel production) as opposed to being used for direct human consumption or animal feed.

title: Share of land area used for agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures.

title: Share of land area used for arable agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-arable-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for arable agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow.

title: Share of land used for permanent meadows and pastures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/area-meadows-and-pastures?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Permanent meadows and pastures is defined by the FAO as: "the land used permanently (five years or more) to grow herbaceous forage crops, either cultivated or growing wild (wild prairie or grazing land)."

title: What has driven the growth in global agricultural production?

subtitle: Global agricultural growth is measured by the average annual change in economic output from agriculture. This is broken down by its drivers in each decade. Productivity growth measures increase output from a given amount of input: it's driven by factors such as efficiency gains, better seed varieties, land reforms, and better management practices.

title: Outdoor air pollution death rate

subtitle: The number of deaths attributed to outdoor particulate matter pollution per 100,000 people.

title: Outdoor air pollution death rate by age
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/outdoor-pollution-rates-by-age?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Death rates are measured as the number of premature deaths attributed to outdoor particulate matter air pollution per 100,000 individuals in each age group.

title: Outdoor air pollution deaths in 1990 vs. 2019
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/outdoor-pollution-deaths-1990-2017?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Deaths from outdoor particulate matter air pollution. Countries below the diagonal line have experienced an increase in deaths, whilst those above the line have seen a decrease.

title: Ozone (O₃) concentration
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ozone-o3-concentration-in-ppb?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Population-weighted average ozone (O₃) concentrations in parts per billion (ppb). Local concentrations of ozone are recorded and estimated at a 11x11km resolution. These values are subsequently weighted by population-density for calculation of nation-level average concentrations.

title: Particulate matter exposure in 1990 vs. 2017
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/pm-exposure-1990-2017?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Population-weighted average level of exposure to concentrations of suspended particles measuring less than 2.5 microns in diameter. Exposure is measured in micrograms per cubic metre (µg/m³).

title: Share of deaths attributed to air pollution
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deaths-air-pollution?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of deaths, from any cause, which are attributed to air pollution – from outdoor and indoor sources – as a risk factor.

title: Share of deaths attributed to outdoor air pollution
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deaths-outdoor-pollution?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of deaths, from any cause, where ambient particulate matter air pollution is a risk factor.

title: Share of population exposed to air pollution above WHO targets
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/exposure-pollution-above-who-targets?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The WHO recommends particulate matter (PM2.5) concentrations of 5 micrograms per cubic as the lower range of air pollution exposure, over which adverse health effects occur. The WHO has set interim targets of exposure for 35µg/m³, 25µg/m³, 15µg/m³, and 10µg/m³.

title: Share of the population exposed to air pollution levels above WHO guidelines
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-above-who-pollution-guidelines?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of the population exposed to outdoor concentrations of particulate matter (PM2.5) that exceed the WHO guideline value of 10 micrograms per cubic meter per year. 10µg/m³ represents the lower range of WHO recommendations for air pollution exposure over which adverse health effects are observed.

title: Share of the population without access to clean fuels for cooking
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-the-population-without-access-to-clean-fuels-for-cooking?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Access to clean fuels or technologies such as natural gas, electricity, and clean cookstoves reduces exposure to indoor air pollutants, a leading cause of death in low-income households.

title: Sources of air pollution in the UK
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/sources-of-air-pollution-in-the-uk?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Emissions of specific air pollutants by source, measured in tonnes per year. This is given as a national annual total.

title: emissions of air pollutants
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/change-air-pollutant-emissions?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Air pollutants are gases that can lead to negative impacts on human health and ecosystems. Most are produced from energy, industry, and agriculture.

title: Active fur farms
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/active-fur-farms?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Fur Free Alliance (2023)

title: Animal lives lost per kilogram of product
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/animal-lives-lost-direct?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The estimated number of animal lives that go toward each kilogram of animal product purchased for retail sale. This only includes direct deaths e.g. the pork numbers include only the deaths of pigs slaughtered for food.

title: Animal lives lost per kilogram of product, including indirect deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/animal-lives-lost-total?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The estimated number of animal lives that go toward each kilogram of animal product purchased for retail sale. This includes direct and indirect deaths e.g. pork numbers include pigs slaughtered for food (direct) but also those who die pre-slaughter and feed fish given to those pigs (indirect).

title: Egg production by system in the United Kingdom
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/egg-production-system?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: 'Cages' includes both battery and 'enriched' cages, which are larger, furnished cages that provide slightly more space. Battery cages have been banned in the UK since 2012.

title: Global number of farmed finfishes used for food
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-farmed-finfishes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Finfish refers to any fish with fins, as opposed to shellfish.

title: Kilograms of meat produced per animal
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/kilograms-meat-per-animal?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The quantity of meat produced per average animal over its lifetime. For example, the average chicken would yield 1.7 kilogram of edible meat.

title: Land animals slaughtered for meat
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-animals-slaughtered-for-meat?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: These numbers do not include additional deaths that happen during the production of meat and dairy, chickens slaughtered in the egg industry, and other land animals for which there is no data.

title: Laying hens in cages and cage-free housing
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/laying-hens-cages-and-cage-free?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Welfare Footprint Project (2022)

title: Levels of pain endured by the average hen in different production systems
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/pain-levels-hen-systems?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimates of the number of days that the average hen will spend in pain over her laying life. A 'day' is considered to be 16 hours, the length of time that the average hen is awake.

title: Number of farmed crustaceans killed for food
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/farmed-crustaceans?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Decapod crustaceans are animals such as shrimps, crabs, lobsters, prawns, and crayfish. This data does not include species without an estimated mean weight (which were an additional 6% of reported global production).

title: Number of farmed fish killed for food
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/farmed-fish-killed?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This data does not include lobsters, farmed fish used as bait, and species without an estimated mean weight (which were an additional 17% of reported global fish production).

title: Number of wild-caught fish killed for food
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/wild-caught-fish?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This data is based on the average tonnage of annual catch from 2007 to 2016, and estimated mean weights for fish species. It does not include unrecorded fish capture, such as fish caught illegally and those caught as bycatch and discards.

title: Public attitudes to bans on factory farming and slaughterhouses in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/attitudes-bans-factory-farming?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The survey measured attitudes towards animal farming with around 1,500 adults in the United States, census-balanced to be representative of age, gender, region, ethnicity, and income.

title: Public attitudes to dietary choices and meat-eating in the United States

subtitle: The survey measured attitudes towards animal farming with around 1,500 adults in the United States, census-balanced to be representative of age, gender, region, ethnicity, and income.

title: Public attitudes to livestock treatment and animal pain in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/survey-animal-pain-sentience?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The survey measured attitudes towards animal farming with around 1,500 adults in the United States, census-balanced to be representative of age, gender, region, ethnicity, and income.

title: Self-reported dietary choices by age, United Kingdom
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/dietary-choices-of-british-adults?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: – Flexitarian: mainly vegetarian, but occasionally eat meat or fish. – Pescetarian: eat fish but do not eat meat or poultry. – Vegetarian: do not eat any meat, poultry, game, fish, or shellfish. – Plant-based / Vegan: do not eat dairy products, eggs, or any other animal product.

title: Share of egg production that is cage-free
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/eggs-cage-free?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of eggs produced by different housing systems
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-eggs-produced-by-different-housing-systems?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Welfare Footprint Project (2022)

title: Time that fast and slower-growing chicken breeds spend in pain over their lifespan
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/pain-broiler-chickens?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimates of the time that an average chicken raised for meat will spend in different levels of pain. Both breeds of chicken reach the same slaughter weight, just at different rates.

title: Vegans, vegetarians and meat-eaters: self-reported dietary choices, United Kingdom
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/dietary-choices-uk?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: – Flexitarian: mainly vegetarian, but occasionally eat meat or fish. – Pescetarian: eat fish but do not eat meat or poultry. – Vegetarian: do not eat any meat, poultry, game, fish, or shellfish. – Plant-based / Vegan: do not eat dairy products, eggs, or any other animal product.

title: Which countries have banned bullfighting?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/bullfighting-ban?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Bullfighting is a physical contest that involves a bullfighter attempting to subdue, immobilize, or kill a bull.

title: Which countries have banned chick culling?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/banning-of-chick-culling?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Chick culling is the process of separating and killing unwanted male and unhealthy female chicks that cannot produce eggs in industrialized egg facilities.

title: Which countries have banned fur farming?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fur-farming-ban?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source:

title: Which countries have banned fur trading?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fur-trading-ban?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Fur Free Alliance (2023)

title: Yearly number of animals slaughtered for meat
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/animals-slaughtered-for-meat?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Antibiotic use in livestock in Europe
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-in-europe?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotics are used in livestock for animal health and productivity, but also pose a risk for antibiotic resistance in both humans and livestock. Data is measured as the milligrams of total antibiotic use per kilogram of meat production. This is corrected for differences in livestock numbers and types, normalising to a population-corrected unit (PCU). A suggested global cap of antibiotic use in livestock is set at 50mg/PCU.

title: Antibiotic use in livestock vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotic use in livestock, measured as the milligrams of total active ingredient used per kilogram of meat production versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita.

title: Antibiotic use in livestock vs. meat supply per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-vs-meat-supply-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotic use in livestock, measured as the milligrams of total active ingredient used per kilogram of meat production versus the average meat supply per capita, measured in kilograms per person per year.

title: Global antibiotic use in livestock under reduction scenarios
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/reduction-global-antibiotic-use?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Projected global antibiotic use in livestock under expected meat consumption levels in 2030, and a range of modeled reduction scenarios based on antibiotic use limits, reductions in meat consumption, and a fee on antibiotic sales. Further details on each scenario are given in the sources tab. Global antibiotic use is measured in tonnes per year.

title: Share of E. coli infections resistant to cephalosporins
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-e-coli-bloodstream-infections-due-to-antimicrobial-resistant-bacteria?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics commonly used to treat E. coli infections. This shows the estimated share of infections by E. coli in the bloodstream that were resistant to 3rd generation cephalosporins.

title: Share of S. aureus infections resistant to methicillin
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-s-aureus-bloodstream-infections-that-are-resistant-to-antibiotics?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Methicillin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat infections by Staphylococcus aureus. This shows the estimated share of infections by S. aureus in the bloodstream that were resistant to methicillin.

title: African elephant carcass ratio
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/african-elephant-carcass-ratio?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Carcass ratio is the number of dead elephants observed during survey counts as a percentage of the total population. Carcass ratios greater than 8% are considered to be a strong indication of a declining population.

title: Annual fish catch relative to mean catch
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-fish-catch-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish catch is measured as annual catch divided by the mean catch over the stock's time series. A value greater than one means annual catch is higher than average over the entire time period.

title: Annual fish catch relative to mean catch by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-catch-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish catch is measured as annual catch divided by the mean catch over the stock's time series. A value greater than one means annual catch is higher than average over the entire time period.

title: Aquaculture production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/aquaculture-farmed-fish-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Aquaculture production specifically refers to output from aquaculture activities, which are designated for final harvest for consumption.

title: Black rhino population
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/black-rhinos?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated number of black rhinos.

title: Capture fishery production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/capture-fishery-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Capture (wild) fishery production does not include seafood produced from fish farming (aquaculture).

title: Change in bird populations in the EU
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/bird-populations-eu?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The bird population index is measured relative to population size in the year 2000 (i.e. the value in 2000 = 100).

title: Change in total mangrove area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/change-in-total-mangrove-area?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Percentage change in mangrove area from the baseline extent of mangroves in 2000.

title: Changes in UK butterfly populations
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/changes-uk-butterfly?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Changes in butterfly populations are measured as an index relative to populations in their start year (1976 or 1990 depending on the species group).

title: Chlorophyll-a deviation from the global average
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/chlorophyll-a-deviation-from-the-global-average?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of satellite imagery pixels measuring chlorophyll-a within a country's Exclusive Economic Zone that are above the 90th percentile of the global baseline (2000-2004). The value given is an annual average of monthly deviations.

title: Countries have a budget for invasive alien species management
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/budget-to-manage-invasive-alien-species?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: An “alien” species is described as one which has been introduced outside its natural distribution range because of human activity. An alien species which then becomes a threat to native biodiversity is known as an "invasive alien species".

title: Countries that are party to the Nagoya Protocol
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/countries-that-are-parties-to-the-nagoya-protocol?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Being party to the Nagoya Protocol means agreeing to follow the rules and guidelines set forth in the agreement, which aim to ensure that the benefits of genetic resources are shared fairly and equitably, and that traditional knowledge is protected and respected.

title: Countries that have legislative measures reported to the Access and Benefit-Sharing Clearing-House
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/countries-to-access-and-benefit-sharing-clearing-house?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Access and Benefit-Sharing Clearing-House Protocol is a supplementary agreement to the Nagoya Protocol that establishes a web-based platform for sharing information on the use of genetic resources and associated traditional knowledge.

title: Countries with more than 25 species at risk of losing more than 25% of their habitat by 2050
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/habitat-loss-25-species?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of species at risk of losing greater than 25% of their habitat as a result of agricultural expansion under business-as-usual projections to 2050. This is shown for countries with more than 25 species at risk.

title: Day of the year with peak cherry tree blossom in Kyoto, Japan
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/date-of-the-peak-cherry-tree-blossom-in-kyoto?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The vertical axis shows the date of peak blossom, expressed as the number of days since 1st January. The timing of the peak cherry blossom is influenced by spring temperatures. Higher temperatures due to climate change have caused the peak blossom to gradually move earlier in the year since the early 20th century.

subtitle: Endemic species are those known to occur naturally within one country only. This includes the exclusive economic zone of a country which is the sea within 200 nautical miles of a country's coastal boundary.

title: Fish and seafood production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-seafood-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish and seafood production is measured as the sum of seafood from wild catch and fish farming (aquaculture).

title: Fish catch in the United Kingdom
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-catch-uk?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total annual landings – fish catch brought back to land – of bottom-living fish. This excludes shellfish.

title: Fish discards
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-discards?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Discards are animals thrown back (alive or dead) into the sea after being caught during fishing activities. This represents bycatch (fish caught unintentionally) that is not brought ashore for use.

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by group
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fishing intensity
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measured the extent to which a stock is being exploited. This is the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Here it's measured as the intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without declining populations. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

title: Fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measures the extent to which a stock is being exploited. Here, it's measured as current fishing intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without causing fish population. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

title: Five centuries of cod catches in Eastern Canada
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/long-term-cod-catch?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimates of North Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) catch off Newfoundland and Labrador, Eastern Canada.

title: Global aquaculture production and wild fish used for animal feed
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-aquaculture-wild-fish-feed?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Some wild fish catch is processed into fishmeal and oils for animal feed – this is used for land-based livestock and fish farms (aquaculture). Efficiency improvements in aquaculture, and changes in the diets of farmed fish means production has increased rapidly, without increasing inputs from wild fish.

subtitle: Wildlife trade is quantified in terms of whole organism equivalents (WOE). For example, five skulls represent five WOEs, whereas it's assumed that four ears are sourced from two animals and so represent two WOEs.

subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here it's measured as the biomass of a fish stock divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

title: Health of fish stocks by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here the biomass of a fish stock is divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield. A value of one maximizes fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

title: Living Planet Index by region

subtitle: The Living Planet Index (LPI) measures the average relative decline in monitored wildlife populations. The index value measures the change in abundance in 38,427 populations across 5,268 species relative to the year 1970 (i.e. 1970 = 100%).

subtitle: Material footprint is the quantity of material needed to meet a country's material demand. It is material production, adjusted for trade. The total material footprint is the sum of the material footprint for biomass, fossil fuels, metal ores, and non-metal ores, given in tonnes per year.

title: Material footprint per unit of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/material-footprint-per-unit-of-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Material footprint is the quantity of material needed to meet a country's material demand. It is material production, adjusted for trade. The total material footprint is the sum of the material footprint for biomass, fossil fuels, metal ores, and non-metal ores.

title: Member countries of the International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/countries-to-the-international-treaty-on-plant-genetic-resources?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The International Treaty on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture is an international agreement that aims to ensure the conservation and sustainable use of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, and to promote the fair and equitable sharing of the benefits derived from their use.

title: Mountain Green Cover Index

subtitle: Mountain Green Cover Index measures the share of mountainous areas covered by either forest, cropland, grassland or wetland. An increase in green mountain cover may reflect either the expansion of natural ecosystems or an increase in the growth of vegetation in areas previously covered by glaciers.

title: National biodiversity strategy and action plan targets align with Aichi Biodiversity Target 9

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions from cement

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions from coal

subtitle: Cumulative emissions of carbon dioxide (CO₂) from coal since the first year of available data, measured as a percentage of global cumulative emissions of CO₂ from coal.

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions from flaring
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-global-cumulative-co2-flaring?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cumulative emissions of carbon dioxide (CO₂) from flaring since the first year of available data, measured as a percentage of global cumulative emissions of CO₂ from flaring.

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions from gas
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-global-cumulative-co2-gas?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cumulative emissions of carbon dioxide (CO₂) from gas since the first year of available data, measured as a percentage of global cumulative emissions of CO₂ from gas.

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions from land-use change
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-global-cumulative-co-emissions-from-land-use-change?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Emissions from land-use change can be positive or negative depending on whether these changes emit (positive) or sequester (negative) carbon. Cumulative emissions are the running sum of emissions since 1850.

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions from other industry
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-global-cumulative-co-emissions-from-other-industry?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of global cumulative CO2 emissions including land-use change

subtitle: Emissions include those from fossil fuels and industry, and land-use change. This is measured as the cumulative total since 1850.

title: Share of global greenhouse gas emissions
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-global-ghg-emissions?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of global greenhouse gas emissions from food

subtitle: Food system emissions include agriculture, land-use change, and supply chain emissions (transport, packaging, food processing, retail, cooking, and waste). Emissions are quantified based on food production, not consumption. This means they do not account for international trade.

title: Share of global methane emissions
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-global-methane-emissions?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of global nitrous oxide emissions

title: Share of national greenhouse gas emissions that come from food

subtitle: Food system emissions include agriculture, land-use change, and supply chain emissions (transport, packaging, food processing, retail, cooking, and waste). Emissions are quantified based on food production, not consumption. This means they do not account for international trade.

title: Value added growth vs. CO2 emissions growth in China

Sectors in the top left quadrant have decoupled their emissions from economic growth - whilst their emissions fell, their economic value grew. Direct emissions of households are not included.

title: Value added growth vs. CO2 emissions growth in Germany
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/value-added-growth-vs-emissions-growth-germany?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

Sectors in the top left quadrant have decoupled their emissions from economic growth - whilst their emissions fell, their economic value grew. Direct emissions of households are not included.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/value-added-growth-vs-emissions-growth-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

Due to varying protocols and challenges in the attribution of the cause of death, the number of confirmed deaths may not accurately represent the true number of deaths caused by COVID-19.

title: Has country already reached SDG target on improved water access?

subtitle: Target 7.1 of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is to achieve universal and equitable usage of safe and affordable drinking water for all. Here, we assume a target threshold of at least 99% using an improved water source.

title: Improved water sources vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/improved-water-sources-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: An improved drinking water source includes piped water on premises and other sources (public taps or standpipes, tube wells or boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs, and rainwater collection). GDP per capita is measured in constant international-$.

title: People not using an improved water source
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-without-improved-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water by nature of their design and construction, and include: piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

title: People not using safe drinking water facilities
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-without-safe-drinking-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Safely managed drinking water is defined as an “Improved source located on premises, available when needed, and free from microbiological and priority chemical contamination.”

title: People using at least a basic drinking water source
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/people-with-access-to-at-least-basic-drinking-water?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Basic drinking water services are defined as an improved drinking water source, provided collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a roundtrip including queuing.

title: Rate of deaths attributed to unsafe water sources
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rates-from-unsafe-water-sources-gbd?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to unsafe water sources per 100,000 people. Here the attributable burden is the number of deaths per 100,000 people that would no longer occur if the entire population had access to high-quality piped water.

Corn (maize) yields are measured in tonnes per hectare.

Installed non-module prices include hardware costs, such as inverters and racking equipment; and the wide assortment of soft costs, including such things as marketing and customer acquisition, system design, installation labor, permitting and inspection costs, and installer margins.

title: Agri-environmental policies weighted by their intensity

subtitle: The number of policies tackling the environmental impacts of agriculture is weighted by the stringency and enforcement of policies, and levels of corruption. title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by group
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-stocks-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.

title: Fishing intensity
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measured the extent to which a stock is being exploited. This is the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year. Here it's measured as the intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without declining populations. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

title: Fishing intensity by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fishing-pressure-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fishing intensity measures the extent to which a stock is being exploited. Here, it's measured as current fishing intensity divided by the intensity at the maximum sustainable yield. A value of one is the optimal level to maximize fish catch without causing fish population. Greater than one suggests overfishing.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-aquaculture-wild-fish-feed?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Some wild fish catch is processed into fishmeal and oils for animal feed – this is used for land-based livestock and fish farms (aquaculture). Efficiency improvements in aquaculture, and changes in the diets of farmed fish means production has increased rapidly, without increasing inputs from wild fish.

title: Global fish discards by type of fishing gear
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-discards-gear?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Discards are animals thrown back (alive or dead) into the sea after being caught during fishing activities.

title: Greenhouse gas emissions per kilogram of seafood
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/ghg-emissions-seafood?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Based on a meta-analysis of data from 1690 fish farms and 1000 unique fishery records. Impacts are given in kilograms of carbon dioxide-equivalents per kilogram of edible weight.

title: Health of fish stocks by fish group
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-taxa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here it's measured as the biomass of a fish stock divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

title: Health of fish stocks by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/biomass-fish-stocks-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Fish stocks are measured by their biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Here the biomass of a fish stock is divided by the biomass at its maximum sustainable yield. A value of one maximizes fish catch without decreasing fish populations.

It is an efficient way of catching fish, but has negative impacts on the ecology of the seabed. – Shown is the share of seabed across different regions that experienced at least one trawling pass over a period of two to four years around the year of 2010.

title: Share of food lost in post-harvest processes

title: Share of food lost in post-harvest processes by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/food-loss-postharvest-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Post-harvest losses are measured as the food lost from the farm level up to, but not including, the retail level. This includes handling and storage, food processing, transport and distribution. It does not include consumer waste.

title: Share of global food loss and waste by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-food-waste-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Food losses and waste includes all supply chain stages, from (and including) on-farm harvesting through to final consumer waste.

title: Local animal breeds with conserved genetic material

subtitle: The number of local animal breeds, those that exist in only one country, with sufficient genetic material stored within genebank collections to allow the reconstitution of the breed in case of extinction.

title: Transboundary animal breeds with conserved genetic material
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-transboundary-animal-breeds-which-have-genetic-resources-secured-in-conservation-facilities?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of transboundary animal breeds, those that exist in more than one country, with sufficient genetic material stored within genebank collections to allow the reconstitution of the breed in case of extinction.

title: Above-ground forest biomass
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/above-ground-biomass-in-forest-per-hectare?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Tonnes of above-ground forest biomass per hectare. Changes in the above-ground forest biomass show the balance between gains from forest growth and losses due to wood removal, natural losses, fire, wind, pests and diseases.

title: Annual CO2 emissions from deforestation by product

subtitle: This measures the amount of CO₂ emissions linked to deforestation for food production – it is trade-adjusted, to reflect the carbon footprint of diets within a given country. It is based on the annual average over the period from 2010 to 2014.

title: Annual CO2 emissions from deforestation for food production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/co2-deforestation-for-food?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Tonnes of CO₂ emissions linked to deforestation for food production – it is trade-adjusted, to reflect the carbon footprint of diets within a given country. Based on the annual average over the period from 2010 to 2014.

title: Annual afforestation
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-afforestation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Afforestation is the establishment of forest through planting and/or deliberate seeding on land that, until then, was not classified as forest.

title: Annual change in forest area

subtitle: The annual net change in forested area as a percentage of total forest area. Negative values indicate a net loss of forest, and positive values indicate a net gain.

title: Annual change in forest area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/annual-change-forest-area?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Net change in forest area measures forest expansion (either through afforestation or natural expansion) minus deforestation

title: Annual change in forest area as a share of forest area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/change-forest-area-share-total?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Annual change in forest area vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/change-forest-vs-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual change in forest area is measured as the five-year average. A positive change in forest area represents reforestation, and negative change represents net deforestation. GDP per capita is measured in constant international-dollars which adjusts for inflation and cross-country price differences.

title: Annual deforestation

title: Annual deforestation as a share of forest area

subtitle: Data source: UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). Forest Resources Assessment.

title: Annual deforestation by region (2010–2014)
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/commodity-deforestation-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual deforestation is measured as the average between 2010 and 2014, and is measured in hectares.

title: Annual forest expansion

subtitle: Forest expansion is the sum of afforestation (the establishment of forest through planting and/or deliberate seeding) and natural forest expansion (expansion of forests through natural succession on land that, until then, was under another land use).

title: Annual tropical deforestation by agricultural product
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deforestation-by-commodity?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual deforestation is measured as the average between 2010 and 2014, and is measured in hectares.

title: Change in domestic forest area vs. deforestation embedded in imported goods
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/domestic-forest-change-vs-imported-deforestation?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A positive change in domestic forest area represents reforestation. Deforestation embedded in imported goods measures deforestation in other countries caused in the production of food and forestry products which are imported. Countries which lie below the dashed line import deforestation at a higher rate than they are reforesting domestically.

title: Change in total mangrove area

title: Drivers of forest loss in the Brazilian Amazon

title: Forest area

title: Forest transition phase
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/forest-transition-phase?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Countries are grouped into four forest transition phases which tend to represent a sequence of development. (1) Pre-transition: high forest cover and low deforestation rates; (2) Early-transition: forests lost at an increasingly rapid rate; (3) Late-transition: small fraction of remaining forest but slowing of deforestation; (4) Post-transition: forest cover increases through reforestation.

subtitle: Years of global coal, oil and natural gas left, reported as the reserves-to-product (R/P) ratio which measures the number of years of production left based on known reserves and present annual production levels. title: Global Hunger Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-hunger-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Global Hunger Index tries to capture the multidimensional nature of hunger by calculating an index score from four key hunger indicators. It is measured on a 100-point scale where 0 is the best score (no hunger) and 100 is the worst.

title: Global Hunger Index vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-hunger-index-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The Global Hunger Index is measured on a 100-point scale where 0 is the best (no hunger) and 100 the worst. GDP per capita is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Inequality in per capita calorie intake
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/coefficient-of-variation-cv-in-per-capita-caloric-intake?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The inequality in dietary calorie intake is measured as the coefficient of variation in energy intake. It represents the spread of intakes around the mean. Higher values represent larger levels of dietary inequality.

title: Inequality of food consumption vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/coefficient-of-variation-in-caloric-consumption-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Inequality of food consumption is measured by the coefficient of variation in per capita caloric consumption. Higher values represent larger levels of dietary inequality. GDP per capita is measured in constant international-dollars.

title: Malnutrition death rate vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/malnutrition-death-rate-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Protein-energy malnutrition (PEM) death rate, measured per 100,000 individuals versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, measured in constant international-$. PEM occurs as a result of insufficient caloric or protein intake.

subtitle: The number of children younger than five who are 'wasted'. Wasting is when a child’s weight is significantly lower than the average for their height, for example because of acute food shortage or disease.

title: Malnutrition: Share of children who are stunted
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/child-stunting-ihme?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of children younger than five years old that are defined as stunted. Stunting is when a child is significantly shorter than the average for their age, as a consequence of poor nutrition and/or repeated infection.

title: Malnutrition: Share of children who are underweight
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-children-underweight?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of children younger than five years old whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population for ages 0-59 months.

title: Malnutrition: Share of children who are wasted
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-children-with-a-weight-too-low-for-their-height-wasting?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Minimum daily requirement of calories

subtitle: The minimum amount of daily dietary energy per person that is considered adequate to ensure they maintain a minimum weight for health. Across a population, this takes factors such as the age, sex, height, and activity levels of different individuals into account.

title: Number of people who are moderately or severely food insecure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-people-moderately-or-severely-food-insecure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Food insecurity is defined by the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES). Moderate food insecurity is associated with the inability to regularly eat healthy, nutritious diets. Severe food insecurity is related to insufficient quantity of food.

title: Number of people who are severely food insecure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-people-severely-food-insecure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Severe food insecurity is defined by the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES). It is strongly related to insufficient quantity of food (energy).

title: Number of people who are undernourished
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-undernourished?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Undernourishment is measured as having a caloric intake that is insufficient to meet the minimum energy requirements necessary for a given individual.

title: Number of severely food insecure people by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-severely-food-insecure-people-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Severe food insecurity is defined by the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES). It is strongly related to insufficient quantity of food (energy).

subtitle: A child is defined as stunted if their height-for-age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. Improved sanitation facilities are those designed to separate excreta from human contact hygienically.

title: Prevalence of undernourishment in developing countries
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/prevalence-of-undernourishment-in-developing-countries-since-1970?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/prevalence-of-undernourishment-vs-share-of-children-who-are-stunted?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of children who are stunted vs. CO2 emissions per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-children-who-are-stunted-vs-co-emissions-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Share of children who are stunted vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/stunting-ihme-vs-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of children who are stunted – significantly shorter than the average for their age. GDP per capita is adjusted for inflation and differences in the cost of living between countries.

title: Share of population with moderate or severe food insecurity
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-population-with-moderate-or-severe-food-insecurity?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Food insecurity is defined by the Food Insecurity Experience Scale (FIES). Moderate food insecurity is associated with the inability to regularly eat healthy, nutritious diets. Severe food insecurity is more related to insufficient quantity of food (energy).

title: Share of population with severe food insecurity
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-population-with-severe-food-insecurity?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Someone suffering from severe food insecurity has an insufficient quantity of food. They will experience symptoms such as physical hunger.

title: Share of the population defined as severely food insecure vs. undernourished
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/severe-food-insecurity-undernourishment?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

Severe food insecurity is measured based on food security questionnaires among households. Undernourishment is based on estimates of actual calorie intake across the population.

title: Share of the population that is undernourished
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/prevalence-of-undernourishment?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of individuals that have a daily food intake that is insufficient to provide the amount of dietary energy required to maintain a normal, active, and healthy life.

title: Share of the population who are undernourished vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-undernourished-vs-gdp-pc?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This is the main FAO hunger indicator. It measures the share of the population that has a caloric intake which is insufficient to meet the minimum energy requirements necessary for a given individual.

title: Stunting vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/stunting-vs-level-of-prosperity-over-time?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Access to clean fuels for cooking vs. GDP per capita

Lack of access to clean fuels results in high levels of indoor air pollution – a key risk factor for respiratory infections.
