subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to household and ambient air pollution per100,000 people.

title: Deaths from household and outdoor air pollution
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-from-household-and-outdoor-air-pollution?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total number of deaths from household and outdoor particulate matter air pollution per year. Household pollution-related deaths result from the use of solid fuels (crop wastes, dung, firewood, charcoal and coal) for cooking and heating.

title: Deaths from indoor air pollution
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/absolute-number-of-deaths-from-household-air-pollution?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Estimated annual number of deaths attributed to indoor air pollution from the use of solid fuels for cooking and heating.

title: Deaths from indoor air pollution, by age
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-from-indoor-air-pollution-by-age?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: IHME, Global Burden of Disease (2019)

title: Has country already reached SDG target on clean cooking fuels?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/sdg-target-on-clean-cooking-fuels?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Target 7.1 of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is to ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services. Here, this is shown as the share of the population with access to clean fuels for cooking and heating.

title: Household air pollution deaths by region
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/household-air-pollution-deaths-by-region?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual number of premature deaths attributed to household air pollution from the use of solid fuels for cooking and heating. Solid fuels include the use of crop wastes, dung, charcoal and coal for indoor cooking.

title: Indoor air pollution death rate vs. access to clean fuels for cooking
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/indoor-pollution-death-rates-clean-fuels?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Indoor air pollution death rates, measured per 100,000 individuals versus the share of the population with access to clean fuels and technologies for cooking.

title: Indoor air pollution vs. outdoor air pollution death rate
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/household-vs-outdoor-air-pollution-death-rates?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The age-standardized death rates from household air pollution (caused by cooking and heating with solid fuels) versus outdoor particulate matter air pollution, measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 individuals. Countries above the comparison line have higher death rates from indoor air pollution than outdoor.

title: Number of deaths from indoor air pollution, 1990 vs. 2019
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/indoor-pollution-deaths-1990-2017?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual number of deaths attributed to indoor air pollution in the year 1990 versus the number in 2019.

title: Share of deaths from indoor air pollution
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deaths-indoor-pollution?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of deaths, from any cause, which are attributed to indoor air pollution – from burning solid fuels – as a risk factor.

title: Share of population using solid fuels as the main cooking fuel
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/population-using-solid-fuels-for-cooking?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Share of households by region who rely on wood, crop residues, dung, charcoal, or coal as the main cooking fuel. Burning these solid fuels can cause illnesses like pneumonia, stroke, heart disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and lung cancer.

title: Share of rural vs. urban population with electricity access
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-rural-population-with-electricity-access-vs-share-of-total-population-with-electricity-access?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Having access to electricity is defined in international statistics as having an electricity source that can provide very basic lighting, and charge a phone or power a radio for 4 hours per day.

title: Share of the population with access to clean fuels for cooking
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/access-to-clean-fuels-and-technologies-for-cooking?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Access to clean fuels or technologies such as natural gas, electricity, and clean cookstoves reduces exposure to indoor air pollutants, a leading cause of death in low-income households.

title: Agricultural area over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-area-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total areal land use for agriculture, measured as the combination of land for arable farming (cropland) and grazing in hectares.

title: Agricultural land per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agricultural-area-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land is the sum of cropland and land used as pasture for grazing livestock.

title: Agricultural land use
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agricultural-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land use is the sum of croplands and pasture – land used for grazing livestock.

title: Agricultural land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This dataset is showing estimates of the total agricultural land area – which is the combination of cropland and grazing land – per person. It is measured in hectares per person.

title: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-pin?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops is calculated as arable land divided by the crop production index (PIN). The crop production index (PIN) here is the sum of crop commodities (minus crops used for animal feed), weighted by commodity prices. This is measured as an index relative to 1961 (where 1961 = 1).

title: Arable land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land is defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops, temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. It is measured in hectares per person.

title: Area of land needed to meet global vegetable oil demand
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/area-land-needed-to-global-oil?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This metric represents the amount of land needed to grow a given crop if it was to meet global vegetable oil demand alone.

title: Breakdown of habitable land area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/breakdown-habitable-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Habitable land is defined as ice- and barren-free land. Agricultural land is the sum of croplands and pasture for grazing.

title: Change in cereal production, yield, land use and population
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/index-of-cereal-production-yield-and-land-use?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: All figures are indexed to the start year of the timeline. This means the first year of the time-series is given the value zero.

title: Contribution to global mean surface temperature rise from agriculture and land use
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-warming-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The global mean surface temperature change as a result of a country or region's cumulative emissions of carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide. This is for land use and agriculture only.

title: Coverage of wetlands
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/coverage-of-wetlands?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Percentage of total land area which is defined as wetland according to the RAMSAR convention.

title: Cropland and pasture per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-pasture-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Pasture – land used for livestock grazing – and cropland are measured in hectares per person. The sum of pasture and cropland is the total land used for agriculture.

title: Cropland area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-area?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2024)

title: Cropland extent over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-use-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total cropland area, measured in hectares. Cropland refers to the area defined by the UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) as 'arable land and permanent crops'.

title: Cropland per person over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-per-person-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total cropland per capita, measured in hectares per person.

title: Dietary land use vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/dietary-land-use-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of global habitable land which would be required for agriculture if everyone in the world adopted the average diet of a given country versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, measured in constant international-$. We currently use approximately 50% of habitable land for agriculture, as shown by the horizontal line.

title: Extent of extensive agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/extent-of-extensive-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The extent of extensive agriculture is defined as ‘minimal’ (less than 1% of land area); ‘common’ (1 to 20% of land area) or ‘widespread’ (more than 20%).

title: Extent of foraging, hunting and gathering
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/extent-of-foraging?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The extent of foraging is defined as ‘minimal’ (less than 1% of land area); ‘common’ (1 to 20% of land area) or ‘widespread’ (more than 20%).

title: Extent of intensive agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/extent-of-intensive-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The extent of intensive agriculture is defined as ‘minimal’ (less than 1% of land area); ‘common’ (1 to 20% of land area) or ‘widespread’ (more than 20%).

title: Extent of pastoralism
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/extent-of-pastoralism?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The extent of pastoralism is defined as ‘minimal’ (less than 1% of land area); ‘common’ (1 to 20% of land area) or ‘widespread’ (more than 20%).

title: FAO projections of arable land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fao-projections-of-arable-land-to-2050?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global land allocated to arable production or permanent crops from 1961-2014, with the UN Food and Agricultural Organization's (FAO) projections to 2050. Land area is measured in hectares.

title: Global agricultural land use by major crop type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-agricultural-land-use-by-major-crop-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global land area used for agricultural production, by major crop category, measured in hectares.

title: Global cropland is still increasing
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-cropland?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cropland is land used to grow crops, excluding pasture used for livestock grazing.

title: Global land spared as a result of cereal yield improvements
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cereal-land-spared?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land sparing is calculated as the amount of additional land that would have been needed to meet global cereal production if average crop yields had not increased since 1961.

title: Global land use since 10,000 BCE
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-land-use-since-10000bc?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Ellis, E. C., Beusen, A. H., & Goldewijk, K. K. (2020). Anthropogenic Biomes: 10,000 BCE to 2015 CE.

title: Grazing land use over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/grazing-land-use-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total land used for grazing, measured in hectares.

title: Has the world passed peak agricultural land?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-peak-agricultural-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land is the sum of cropland and pasture used for grazing livestock. This is shown for three sources, which use different methods of estimation. While they disagree on how much land is used for agriculture, and the exact date that it peaked, they do all agree that we have passed the peak.

title: How much cropland has the world spared due to increases in crop yields?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-sparing-by-crop?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land sparing is calculated as the amount of additional land that would have been needed to meet crop production if global average crop yields had not increased since 1961.

title: How much global land is used as pasture for livestock?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-pasture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The extent of global pasture used for livestock grazing. It does not include cropland used to grow animal feed.

title: Is agricultural land expanding? Change over the prior decade
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agriculture-more-less-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land area is compared to its area 10 years before. Positive values (shown in red) indicate an expansion of agriculture. Negative values (in blue) show a decline. Agricultural land is the sum of croplands and pasture used for livestock grazing.

title: Land area in hectares
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-area-hectares?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total land area, measured in hectares. 100 hectares is one square kilometer. Land area is a country's total area, excluding area under inland water bodies, national claims to continental shelf, and exclusive economic zones. In most cases the definition of inland water bodies includes major rivers and lakes.

title: Land area in square kilometres
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-area-km?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total land area, measured in square kilometres (km²). Land area is a country's total area, excluding area under inland water bodies, national claims to continental shelf, and exclusive economic zones. In most cases the definition of inland water bodies includes major rivers and lakes.

title: Land area per crop type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-area-per-crop-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Land use
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2024)

title: Land use for palm oil production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-palm-oil?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Land use for vegetable oil crops
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-for-vegetable-oil-crops?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Land use of foods per 1000 kilocalories
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-kcal-poore?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land use is measured in meters squared (m²) required to produce 1000 kilocalories of a given food product.

title: Land use over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total land area used for cropland, grazing land and built-up areas (villages, cities, towns and human infrastructure).

title: Land use per 100 grams of protein
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-protein-poore?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land use is measured in meters squared (m²) per 100 grams of protein across various food products.

title: Land use per kilogram of food product
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-per-kg-poore?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land use is measured in meters squared (m²) per kilogram of a given food product.

title: Land use vs. yield change in cereal production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-vs-yield-change-in-cereal-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Indexed change in land used for cereal production versus cereal yields, from 1961 to 2014. Both indexes are measured relative to values in 1961 (i.e. 1961 = 100).

title: Land used for agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-agriculture-longterm?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land use is the sum of croplands and pasture – land used for grazing livestock. It is measured in hectares.

title: Organic agricultural area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/organic-agricultural-area?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total organic area is defined as the land area certified as organic, or in the conversion process to organic (over a two-year period). It is the portion of land area (including arable lands, pastures or wild areas) managed (cultivated) or wild harvested in accordance with specific organic standards.

title: Projections for global peak agricultural land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/projections-for-global-peak-agricultural-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Projected trends in global agricultural area extent by various sources, measured in hectares. Projections include those from the UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), International Assessment of Agricultural Knowledge, Science and Technology for Development (IAASTD); OECD, and scenarios from the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MEA). Also shown is the actual agricultural area to 2014, as reported by the UN FAO.

title: Share of adults who perceive their rights to land as secure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-adults-who-perceive-their-rights-to-land-as-secure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The landholder is considered to perceive their land rights as secure if they both: i) do not report a fear of involuntary loss of the land within the next five years, and ii) report having the right to bequeath the land.

title: Share of adults with legal documentation of their rights to land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/legally-recognized-rights-to-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The proportion of the total adult population with secure tenure rights to land, recognized with legal documentation.

title: Share of arable land which is organic
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-arable-land-which-is-organic?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Organic arable land area is the sum of the area certified as organic by official standards, and land area in the conversion process to organic (which is assumed by the UN FAO as a two-year period prior to certification). Arable land is that used for crops (which does not include grazing land).

title: Share of deforestation that is driven by domestic consumption
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deforestation-domestic-consumption?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of national deforestation that is driven by the production of goods that are consumed within domestic markets i.e. not exported to other countries.

title: Share of global habitable land needed for agriculture if everyone had the diet of...
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-global-habitable-land-needed-for-agriculture-if-everyone-had-the-diet-of?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of global habitable land area needed for agriculture if the total world population was to adopt the average diet of any given country. Values greater than 100% are not possible within global land constraints.

title: Share of land area used for agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures.

title: Share of land area used for arable agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-arable-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for arable agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow.

title: Share of land covered by lakes and rivers
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-covered-by-lakes-and-rivers?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of total land area that is made up of lakes and rivers all year round.

title: Share of land defined as natural habitat
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-natural-share?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Natural ecosystems include forest, grassland, savanna, and shrublands, and other classes such as peatlands and marshes. It is total land minus land that is used by humans for agriculture – either croplands or pasture – or for infrastructure and urban environments.

title: Share of land that is degraded
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-degraded-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land degradation is defined as the reduction or loss of the biological or economic productivity of land resulting from a combination of pressures, including land use and management practices.

title: Share of land used for permanent meadows and pastures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/area-meadows-and-pastures?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Permanent meadows and pastures is defined by the FAO as: "the land used permanently (five years or more) to grow herbaceous forage crops, either cultivated or growing wild (wild prairie or grazing land)."

title: Share of mountain land that is degraded
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-mountain-land-that-is-degraded?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Degraded land is land that has lost biological or economic productivity and complexity due to pressures from land use or management practices.

title: Share of rural land area where the elevation is 5 meters or less
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/rural-land-below-5-meters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Multiple sources compiled by World Bank (2024)

title: Share of world regions with land use present
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-regions-with-land-use?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Stephens et al. (2019). Archaeological assessment reveals Earth’s early transformation through land use. Science.

title: Terrain Ruggedness Index
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/terrain-ruggedness-index?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Indicates how jagged or flat the terrain of a country is on average. Ruggedness is measured in metres of elevation difference for grid points 30 arc-seconds (926 metres on the equator or any meridian) apart.

title: Tractors per 100 square kilometers of arable land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/tractors-per-100-square-kilometers-of-arable-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Tractors used in agriculture per 100 square kilometers of arable land.

title: Agricultural area over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-area-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total areal land use for agriculture, measured as the combination of land for arable farming (cropland) and grazing in hectares.

title: Agricultural land per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/agricultural-area-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Agricultural land is the sum of cropland and land used as pasture for grazing livestock.

title: Agricultural land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-agricultural-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This dataset is showing estimates of the total agricultural land area – which is the combination of cropland and grazing land – per person. It is measured in hectares per person.

title: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-pin?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land needed to produce a fixed quantity of crops is calculated as arable land divided by the crop production index (PIN). The crop production index (PIN) here is the sum of crop commodities (minus crops used for animal feed), weighted by commodity prices. This is measured as an index relative to 1961 (where 1961 = 1).

title: Arable land use per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/arable-land-use-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Arable land is defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops, temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow. It is measured in hectares per person.

title: Change of cereal yield and land used for cereal production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/change-of-cereal-yield-vs-land-used?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Cropland extent over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-use-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total cropland area, measured in hectares. Cropland refers to the area defined by the UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO) as 'arable land and permanent crops'.

title: Cropland per person over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cropland-per-person-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total cropland per capita, measured in hectares per person.

title: Dietary land use vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/dietary-land-use-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of global habitable land which would be required for agriculture if everyone in the world adopted the average diet of a given country versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita, measured in constant international-$. We currently use approximately 50% of habitable land for agriculture, as shown by the horizontal line.

title: FAO projections of arable land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fao-projections-of-arable-land-to-2050?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global land allocated to arable production or permanent crops from 1961-2014, with the UN Food and Agricultural Organization's (FAO) projections to 2050. Land area is measured in hectares.

title: Global agricultural land use by major crop type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-agricultural-land-use-by-major-crop-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global land area used for agricultural production, by major crop category, measured in hectares.

title: Global land spared as a result of cereal yield improvements
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cereal-land-spared?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Land sparing is calculated as the amount of additional land that would have been needed to meet global cereal production if average crop yields had not increased since 1961.

title: Grazing land use over the long-term
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/grazing-land-use-over-the-long-term?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total land used for grazing, measured in hectares.

title: Land use vs. yield change in cereal production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/land-use-vs-yield-change-in-cereal-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Indexed change in land used for cereal production versus cereal yields, from 1961 to 2014. Both indexes are measured relative to values in 1961 (i.e. 1961 = 100).

title: Organic agricultural area
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/organic-agricultural-area?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total organic area is defined as the land area certified as organic, or in the conversion process to organic (over a two-year period). It is the portion of land area (including arable lands, pastures or wild areas) managed (cultivated) or wild harvested in accordance with specific organic standards.

title: Projections for global peak agricultural land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/projections-for-global-peak-agricultural-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Projected trends in global agricultural area extent by various sources, measured in hectares. Projections include those from the UN Food and Agricultural Organization (FAO), International Assessment of Agricultural Knowledge, Science and Technology for Development (IAASTD); OECD, and scenarios from the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment (MEA). Also shown is the actual agricultural area to 2014, as reported by the UN FAO.

title: Share of arable land which is organic
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-arable-land-which-is-organic?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Organic arable land area is the sum of the area certified as organic by official standards, and land area in the conversion process to organic (which is assumed by the UN FAO as a two-year period prior to certification). Arable land is that used for crops (which does not include grazing land).

title: Share of global habitable land needed for agriculture if everyone had the diet of...
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-global-habitable-land-needed-for-agriculture-if-everyone-had-the-diet-of?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of global habitable land area needed for agriculture if the total world population was to adopt the average diet of any given country. Values greater than 100% are not possible within global land constraints.

title: Share of land area used for agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Agricultural land refers to the share of land area that is arable, under permanent crops, and under permanent pastures.

title: Share of land area used for arable agriculture
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-land-area-used-for-arable-agriculture?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of land area used for arable agriculture, measured as a percentage of total land area. Arable land includes land defined by the FAO as land under temporary crops (double-cropped areas are counted once), temporary meadows for mowing or for pasture, land under market or kitchen gardens, and land temporarily fallow.

title: Share of land used for permanent meadows and pastures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/area-meadows-and-pastures?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Permanent meadows and pastures is defined by the FAO as: "the land used permanently (five years or more) to grow herbaceous forage crops, either cultivated or growing wild (wild prairie or grazing land)."

title: Share of total energy used in agriculture and forestry
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-of-total-energy-used-in-agriculture-and-forestry?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The share of energy consumed within the agricultural and forestry sectors, measured as the percentage of total energy consumption across all sectors.

title: Tractors per 100 square kilometers of arable land
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/tractors-per-100-square-kilometers-of-arable-land?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Tractors used in agriculture per 100 square kilometers of arable land.

title: Death rate from lead exposure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/death-rate-lead-exposure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Death rates are measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 people.

title: Disease burden from lead exposure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/disease-burden-lead?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disease burden is measured in disability-adjusted life years (DALYs).

title: Global phase-out of leaded petrol in road vehicles
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-petrol-ban?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: All countries have banned the use of leaded petrol in road vehicles. Algeria was the final country to do so in 2021.

title: Lead concentrations in the blood of children in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-blood-usa-children?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Lead concentrations measured in blood samples from children aged one to five years old. Children are particularly vulnerable to lead poisoning and can suffer permanent impacts on the development of the brain and nervous system.

title: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of adults
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-concentrations-blood-adults?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of adults aged 14 and over between 2010 and 2019. There is no defined 'safe' level for lead blood concentrations. The WHO adopts a threshold of 5 µg/dL as an achievable maximum level.

title: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of children
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-concentrations-blood-children?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Mean lead concentrations in the blood of children aged 0 to 14 years old between 2010 and 2019. There is no defined 'safe' level for lead blood concentrations. The WHO adopts a threshold of 5 µg/dL as an achievable maximum level in children.

title: Number of children with lead levels in blood greater than 10 µg/dL
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/children-lead-10micrograms?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Children are defined as those aged 0 to 14 years old. There is no defined 'safe' level for lead blood concentrations. The WHO adopts a threshold of 5 µg/dL as an achievable maximum level in children.

title: Number of children with lead levels in blood greater than 5 µg/dL
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/children-lead-5micrograms?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of children with blood lead levels above the World Health Organization’s ‘acceptable’ threshold. Children are defined as those aged 0 to 14 years old.

title: Number of premature deaths from lead exposure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-lead-exposure?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: IHME, Global Burden of Disease (2019)

title: Rate of disease burden from lead exposure
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/rate-disease-burden-lead?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disease burden is measured in disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). DALYs include the years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with a disability. One DALY equals one lost year of healthy life. This is expressed as a rate per 100,000 people.

title: Share of paints with lead levels greater than 10,000 ppm
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-paint-over-10000ppm?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Lead paint is thought to be a significant contributor to lead poisoning; many countries have therefore implemented a regulatory limit of 90 parts per million (ppm) or 600ppm per weight of dry paint.

title: Share of paints with lead levels greater than 600 ppm
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-paint-over-600ppm?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Lead paint is thought to be a significant contributor to lead poisoning; many countries have therefore implemented a regulatory limit of 90 parts per million (ppm) or 600ppm per weight of dry paint.

title: Share of paints with lead levels greater than 90 ppm
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/lead-paint-over-90ppm?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Lead paint is thought to be a significant contributor to lead poisoning; many countries have therefore implemented a regulatory limit of 90 parts per million (ppm) or 600ppm per weight of dry paint.

title: Which countries have legally-binding controls on lead paint?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/legal-controls-lead-paint?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Paint is a main contributor to harmful lead exposure. The stringency of controls on lead paint can vary by country. Maximum concentrations of lead can differ, and may only apply to particular types of paint (for example, products used in households).

title: Antibiotic use in livestock in Europe
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-in-europe?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotics are used in livestock for animal health and productivity, but also pose a risk for antibiotic resistance in both humans and livestock. Data is measured as the milligrams of total antibiotic use per kilogram of meat production. This is corrected for differences in livestock numbers and types, normalising to a population-corrected unit (PCU). A suggested global cap of antibiotic use in livestock is set at 50mg/PCU.

title: Antibiotic use in livestock vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotic use in livestock, measured as the milligrams of total active ingredient used per kilogram of meat production versus gross domestic product (GDP) per capita.

title: Antibiotic use in livestock vs. meat supply per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/antibiotic-use-in-livestock-vs-meat-supply-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Antibiotic use in livestock, measured as the milligrams of total active ingredient used per kilogram of meat production versus the average meat supply per capita, measured in kilograms per person per year.

title: Aquaculture production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/aquaculture-farmed-fish-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Aquaculture is the farming of aquatic organisms including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and aquatic plants. Aquaculture production specifically refers to output from aquaculture activities, which are designated for final harvest for consumption.

title: Beef production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/beef-and-buffalo-meat-production-tonnes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Capture fishery production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/capture-fishery-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Capture (wild) fishery production does not include seafood produced from fish farming (aquaculture).

title: Cattle meat per animal
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/cattle-meat-yields-hectograms-100-grams-per-animal?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Chicken meat production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/chicken-meat-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Chicken meat production is measured in tonnes per year.

title: Chicken meat yield per animal
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/chicken-meat-yields-per-animal?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Average meat yield per carcass, measured in kilograms per chicken.

title: Daily meat consumption per person
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/daily-meat-consumption-per-person?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Daily meat consumption is shown relative to the expected EU average of 165g per person in 2030. This projection comes from the livestock antibiotic scenarios from Van Boeckel et al. (2017).

title: Dietary land use vs. beef consumption
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/dietary-land-use-vs-beef-consumption?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The percentage of global habitable land area needed for agriculture if the total world population was to adopt the average diet of any given country versus annual per capita beef consumption. Globally we use approximately 50% of habitable land for agriculture, as shown by the grey horizontal line.

title: Egg production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/egg-production-thousand-tonnes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (2023)

title: Egg production by system in the United Kingdom
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/egg-production-system?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: 'Cages' includes both battery and 'enriched' cages, which are larger, furnished cages that provide slightly more space. Battery cages have been banned in the UK since 2012.

title: Eggs per bird
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/egg-yield-per-bird?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual egg yield per bird, measured in kilograms per animal.

title: Energy efficiency of meat and dairy production
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/energy-efficiency-of-meat-and-dairy-production?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The energy efficiency of meat and dairy production is defined as the percentage of energy (caloric) inputs as feed effectively converted to animal product. An efficiency of 25% would mean 25% of calories in animal feed inputs were effectively converted to animal product; the remaining 75% would be lost during conversion.

title: Environmental footprints of dairy and plant-based milks
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/environmental-footprint-milks?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Impacts are measured per liter of milk. These are based on a meta-analysis of food system impact studies across the supply chain which includes land use change, on-farm production, processing, transport, and packaging.

title: Feed required to produce one kilogram of meat or dairy product
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/feed-required-to-produce-one-kilogram-of-meat-or-dairy-product?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Quantity of animal feed required to produce one kilogram of meat, egg or milk product. This is measured as dry matter feed in kilograms per kilogram of edible weight output.

title: Fish and seafood consumption per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-and-seafood-consumption-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data is inclusive of all fish species and major seafood commodities, including crustaceans, cephalopods and other mollusc species.

title: Fish and seafood consumption vs. GDP per capita
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/fish-consumption-vs-gdp-per-capita?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Gross domestic product (GDP) per capita is measured in constant international-$. International dollars correct for price differences across countries.

title: Fish and seafood production

title: Global meat demand if everyone ate like the average citizen of...

subtitle: Hypothetical global meat demand if everyone in the world ate the same quantity as the average citizen of a given country. embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/damage-costs-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Total economic cost of damages as a result of global natural disasters in any given year, measured in current US$. Includes those from drought, floods, extreme weather, extreme temperature, landslides, dry mass movements, wildfires, volcanic activity and earthquakes.

title: Global injuries from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-injured-from-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global number of people injured from natural disaster events. This is defined as "people suffering from physical injuries, trauma or an illness requiring immediate medical assistance as a direct result of a disaster."

title: Global natural disaster death rates
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disaster-death-rates?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Death rates from natural disasters are measured as the number of deaths per 100,000 individuals.

title: Global number of reported disasters by size
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-by-yearly-impact?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: ‘Small’ events have 5 or fewer deaths, less than 1,500 people affected, or reported economic damages below US$13 million. ‘Large’ events have at least 50 deaths, more than 150,000 people affected, or reported economic damages of at least US$320 million. At least part of the increase in small and medium reported events is due to improved reporting over time.

title: Global number of reported disasters by size per decade
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-by-decadal-size?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: ‘Small’ events have 5 or fewer deaths, less than 1,500 people affected, or reported economic damages below US$13 million. ‘Large’ events have at least 50 deaths, more than 150,000 people affected, or reported economic damages of at least US$320 million. At least part of the increase in small and medium reported events is due to improved reporting over time.

title: Global number of reported natural disasters by the number of deaths
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-reported-by-deaths?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of disaster events recorded in the EM-DAT disaster database, broken down by the size of the event, in terms of deaths. There has been an increase in the number of the smallest events – with over 200 deaths – at least partly due to improvements in recording over time.

title: Global precipitation anomaly
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/global-precipitation-anomaly?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: This indicator shows annual anomalies compared with the average precipitation from 1901 to 2000 based on rainfall and snowfall measurements from land-based weather stations worldwide.

title: Global reported natural disasters by type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disasters-by-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The annual reported number of natural disasters, categorised by type. The number of global reported natural disaster events in any given year. Note that this largely reflects increases in data reporting, and should not be used to assess the total number of events.

title: Global weather disaster losses as a share of GDP
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/weather-losses-share-gdp?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global disaster losses from weather- and climate-related events in economic terms, expressed as a share of global gross domestic product (GDP). Economic loss data from disasters is based on figures reported by Munich Re.

title: How many deaths does it take for a disaster in different continents to receive news coverage?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/how-many-deaths-does-it-take-for-a-disaster-in-different-continents-to-receive-news-coverage?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disaster occurrence and news coverage data is used to compute the casualties ratio. The casualties ratio indicates how many casualties would make media coverage (in major US networks) equally likely, all else equal.

title: How many deaths does it take for a disaster to receive news coverage?
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/how-many-deaths-does-it-take-for-a-disaster-to-receive-news-coverage?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Disaster occurrence and news coverage data is used to compute the casualties ratio. The casualties ratio indicates how many casualties would make media coverage (in major US networks) equally likely, all else equal.

title: Hurricane landfalls in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/hurricane-landfalls-us?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Hurricanes are categorised by the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale (SSHWS) which classifies by five categories (1 being the lowest; 5 the highest). Hurricanes reaching Category 3 and higher are considered major hurricanes because of their potential for significant loss of life and damage.

title: Near-Earth asteroids discovered over time
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/near-earth-asteroids-discovered-over-time?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Cumulative number of discovered asteroids with an orbit that brings them into proximity with Earth. This is broken down by size of the asteroid.

title: News coverage of disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/news-coverage-of-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The data considers disasters occurring between 1968-2002 and their corresponding coverage in major US networks. It is evident that "spectacular" disasters receive more coverage.

title: News coverage of disasters, by continent
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/news-coverage-of-disasters-by-continent?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The data considers disasters occurring between 1968-2002 and their corresponding coverage in major US networks.

title: Number of North Atlantic hurricanes
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/frequency-north-atlantic-hurricanes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Major hurricanes are defined as those of category 3, 4 or 5 on the Saffir–Simpson hurricane wind scale (SSHWS). The SSHWS classifies storms based on the intensity of sustained winds. Major hurricanes have potential for significant loss of life and damage.

title: Number of deaths from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-deaths-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: EM-DAT, CRED / UCLouvain (2024)

title: Number of deaths from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/natural-disaster-deaths-ihme?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual number of deaths from all forms of natural disasters.

title: Number of deaths from natural disasters by type
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-from-natural-disasters-by-type?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global estimates of the number of deaths from natural disasters, differentiated by disaster type.

title: Number of local governments with disaster risk reduction strategies
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/local-govts-risk-reduction?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Number of local governments that have adopted and implemented local disaster risk reduction strategies in line with the national strategy.

title: Number of recorded natural disaster events
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-natural-disaster-events?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of global reported natural disaster events in any given year. Note that this largely reflects increases in data reporting, and should not be used to assess the total number of events.

title: Number of significant earthquakes
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/significant-earthquakes?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A significant earthquake meets at least one of the following: caused deaths, moderate damage ($1 million or more), a magnitude 7.5 or greater, Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI) X or greater, or generated a tsunami. Due to data availability, recent data will be more complete than older historical estimates.

title: Number of significant volcanic eruptions
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/significant-volcanic-eruptions?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: A significant eruption is classified as one that meets at least one of the following criteria: caused fatalities, caused moderate damage (approximately $1 million or more), with a Volcanic Explosivity Index (VEI) of 6 or larger, caused a tsunami, or was associated with a major earthquake.

title: Number of tsunamis
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-of-tsunamis?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: National Geophysical Data Center / World Data Service (2024)

title: Number of wildfires in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/wildfire-numbers-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The number of wildfire events in the United States. Data is shown from 1983 onwards, when comparable data records began.

title: People affected by natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/total-affected-by-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global total number of people affected by natural disasters. This is defined as the sum of the injured, affected and those left homeless after a disaster.

title: People displaced internally by natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/internally-displaced-persons-from-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Internally-displaced persons are defined as people or groups of people who have been forced or obliged to flee or to leave their homes or places of habitual residence, as a result of natural or human-made disasters and who have not crossed an international border.

title: People left homeless from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/number-homeless-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Global number of people left homeless from natural disaster events. This is defined as "number of people whose house is destroyed or heavily damaged and therefore need shelter after an event."

title: Precipitation anomaly in the United States
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/precipitation-anomaly?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Annual anomalies compared with the average precipitation from 1901 to 2000 based on rainfall and snowfall measurements from land-based weather stations. Anomalies across all US states were then aggregated based on weighted averages (by area) to define a national result.

title: Projected number of air conditioning units
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/air-conditioners-projections?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data from 2017 onwards is projections from the International Energy Agency, based on estimated changes in population and income.

title: Rate of deaths and missing persons due to natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/deaths-and-missing-persons-due-to-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The annual number of deaths and missing persons due to all forms of natural disaster per 100,000 people.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/legislative-provisions-for-managing-disaster-risk?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Score from 0 (worst) to 1 (best) measuring alignment of country disaster risk reduction strategies with the Sendai Framework.

title: Seasonal temperature anomaly in the United States

subtitle: Seasonal temperature anomaly, compared to the 1901–2000 average temperature. Measured in degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Share of US land that experienced extreme one-day precipitation

subtitle: The share of land area in the United States that experienced an extreme single-day precipitation event.

title: Share of US land with unusually high annual precipitation

subtitle: Share of land area in the United States which experienced unusually high annual precipitation in a given year. This compares actual yearly precipitation totals with expected totals based on historical data.

title: Share of US land with unusually high summer temperatures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/high-summer-temp-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Unusually hot summers are defined based on daily maximum temperatures. At each station, the recorded highs are compared with the full set of historical records. After averaging over a particular month or season of interest, the warmest 10% of years are defined as “unusually hot”.

title: Share of US land with unusually low winter temperatures
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/low-winter-temps-usa?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Unusually cold winter temperatures are measured based on daily minimum temperatures. At each station, the recorded lows are compared with the full set of historical records. After averaging over a particular month or season of interest, the coldest 10 percent of years are defined as “unusually cold.”

title: Share of deaths from natural disasters
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/share-deaths-from-natural-disasters?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: The estimated share of deaths from exposure to forces of nature.

subtitle: The share of disaster events recorded in the widely-cited EM-DAT database with missing data for a given metric. This was measured over the period from 1990 to 2020.

title: Share of households with air conditioning
embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/households-air-conditioning?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>
subtitle: Data source: International Energy Agency (IEA). Future of Cooling.

subtitle: Measured in kilowatt-hours of primary energy per person, using the substitution method.

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/nuclear-non-proliferation-treaty?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

embedding: <iframe src="https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/partial-nuclear-test-ban-treaty?tab=map" loading="lazy" style="width: 100%; height: 600px; border: 0px none;" allow="web-share; clipboard-write"></iframe>

title: Estimated explosive power of nuclear weapons deliverable in first strike
